channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Reaction to the Manning Verdict
item.description: Pfc. Bradley Manning was an Army intelligence analyst who provided some 700,000 secret documents to WikiLeaks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Juan David Ochoa Vásquez, Co-Founder of Medellín Cartel, Dies at 65
item.description: The cocaine trafficker, who started the brutal organization with his brothers and Pablo Escobar, served about five years in prison and then returned to raising horses.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Lens Blog: An Indigenous Way of Life Threatened by Oil Sands in Canada
item.description: The Toronto-based photographer Ian Willms went to Alberta, Canada, to document the profitable yet hazardous oil sands, which have disfigured the landscape and its indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: Manning Is Acquitted of Aiding the Enemy
item.description: Pfc. Bradley Manning was convicted of multiple counts of violating the Espionage Act for leaking documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks, but was found not guilty of the more serious charge of “aiding the enemy.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Mediating as French Culture and Economics Collide
item.description: Aurélie Filippetti, a novelist, is finding new kinds of criticism as France’s minister of culture and communication.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Aurélie Filippetti, a novelist, is the French minister of culture and communication.

item.title: Driver in Fatal Spanish Train Was on Phone, Court Says
item.description: Data from two “black boxes” show that the driver, Francisco Jose Garzon Amo, was on the phone with a colleague and traveling at almost twice the speed limit.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: The driver, Francisco José Garzón Amo, was taken in a police car to a courtroom in Santiago on Sunday.

item.title: Pentagon Report Foresees Continued Support for Afghanistan
item.description: The twice-yearly assessment notes progress but says outside help for Afghan forces will be required long after the NATO-led mission ends at the end of 2014.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Kerry Says Goal Is Mideast Peace Deal Within 9 Months
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said that Israeli and Palestinian negotiators would convene again in the Middle East within two weeks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 30
item.description: A shopkeeper selling garlands made of Indian rupees, in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A shopkeeper in New Delhi selling garlands made of Indian rupees, worn by bridegrooms as a symbol of good luck.

item.title: The Lede: Protesters in Rio Keep Asking, ‘Who Threw the Molotov?’ and ‘Where Is Amarildo?’
item.description: Mistrust between protesters and the police in Rio de Janeiro is running high, as the identity of a bomb-thrower remains unknown and the authorities have no answer for questions about what happened to a man who disappeared after being detained.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and SERGIO PEÇANHA
item.media:credit: Rio de Janeiro Military Police, via YouTube
item.media:description: A police edit of video recorded during a protest in Rio de Janeiro on July 22 compared the T-shirts of a masked man who threw a Molotov cocktail and a man identified as an undercover officer.

item.title: The Lede: Video of the Pope’s ‘Gay Lobby’ Remarks
item.description: “We must distinguish the fact that a person is gay from the fact of lobbying, because no lobbies are good,” Pope Francis told reporters on Monday. “If a person is gay, and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: India Ink: Bihar School Deaths Highlight India’s Struggle With Pesticides
item.description: India continues to widely use toxic pesticides banned in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MEERA SUBRAMANIAN
item.media:description: A farmer sprinkling pesticide in his paddy field in Visalpur village on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, Gujarat, on July 30, 2012.

item.title: India Ink: Congress Party Supports Creation of Telangana State
item.description: Telangana will be the 29th state of India after it goes through the legislative process.
item.dc:creator: By SRIRAM KARRI
item.media:description: A protester braving a police water cannon during a demonstration in New Delhi on Sept. 4, 2012, seeking a separate state of Telangana.

item.title: The Female Factor: A Male Heir, but a Throne Fit for Queens
item.description: In the 21st century, the royal role-model-effect looks very different, and the institution of the British monarchy itself has become increasingly "feminized."
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Six Decades Later, a Second Rescue Attempt
item.description: Harsh weather in North Korea prevented a Navy pilot from retrieving the remains of a fellow airman killed 63 years ago in one of the fiercest battles of the Korean War.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The aircraft carrier Boxer in June 1952 off the Korean coast.

item.title: Pakistani Lawmakers Choose Next President
item.description: The legislators picked Mamnoon Hussain, a Karachi industrialist and the candidate of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif’s party, for the largely ceremonial post.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: European Union Official Says Ousted Egyptian Leader is Doing ‘Well’
item.description: Catherine Ashton’s talks with Mohamed Morsi are the first time Mr. Morsi, the former Egyptian president, has met with an international diplomat since he was taken into military custody.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A picture of Egypt’s ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, on a barricade in Nasr City, Cairo, the site of a sit-in by Islamists angry about the change in leadership.

item.title: South Korean Court Tells Japanese Company to Pay for Forced Labor
item.description: The high court in Busan, in southeastern South Korea, ordered Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to pay $71,800 each to five Koreans forced into work during the colonial period.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Cambodia Government Rejects Opposition Call for Poll Inquiry
item.description: Cambodia’s government rejected calls by the newly energized opposition for an international inquiry into allegations it used massive fraud to win re-election.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Nearly 250 Captives Escape in Pakistan Prison Attack
item.description: More than 100 militants armed with rocket-propelled grenades and heavy arms blasted the prison walls, freeing 243 prisoners including 30 militants.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Despite Gains, Leader of U.S. Forces in Afghanistan Says Troops Must Stay
item.description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the commander of American and allied forces in Afghanistan, said Afghan forces are doing most of the fighting, but they won’t be completely independent by 2014.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the commander of American and allied forces in Afghanistan, in his Kabul office. “Our presence post-2014 is necessary,” he said in an interview Sunday evening.

item.title: Jewel Theft Stuns French Riviera for Its Simplicity
item.description: The theft of more than $136 million in jewels from a luxury hotel in Cannes is among a rash of robberies that have raised questions among insurers, industry insiders and law enforcement agencies.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ahmadinejad Granted License to Start University
item.description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, whose tumultuous two-term tenure is in its final few days, will be moving to academia.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Deadly Explosions Hit Christian Area in North
item.description: Multiple explosions on Monday night rocked a Christian area in the northern city of Kano. Security forces ferried scores of wounded to hospitals.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Prime Minister Calls for December Elections
item.description: Prime Minister Ali Laarayedh announced Monday that elections would be held Dec. 17 and said the government would stay in office to see through the transition.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
